awd_titl_txt: ERI: Towards Safe Aviation Autonomy: A Risk-bounded Planning Framework for Dynamical Systems under Uncertainties
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This Engineering Research Initiation (ERI) award supports research to enable safe operations in the increasingly autonomous environment that comprises the national airspace system (NAS). Development and adoption of drone delivery systems, urban air mobility, and commercial space transportation make it critical to integrate these modes into the current NAS. Unsegregated and efficient operations are very challenging when congested airspace is shared by high volume drone traffic and reserve aircraft hazard areas during space launches. Increasing autonomy in the NAS can help relieve congestion by increasing traffic density in limited airspace but demands high assurance of safe operations. This project will study risk-bounded planning and operations for the integration of these multiple air traffic modes and will provide the autonomous systems community with an underlying theory, set of models, and solution algorithms for risk-bounded planning in the dynamical and uncertain environment that comprises the NAS.
 
The project will develop the methodological foundations for risk-bounded planning of dynamical systems under uncertain environments. Within this framework, the project will study risk-bounded planning algorithms and a distributed computing approach to integrate autonomous operations within the NAS. The project will deliver three innovative techniques to support planning and operations in the NAS environment: (I) a data-driven method for efficient characterization of uncertainty with dynamical data; (II) a suite of risk-bounded planning algorithms based on chance constraints and convex approximation for dynamical systems under uncertainties; (III) a distributed computing framework with a multi-scale approach that can efficiently solve the chance-constrained models accounting for generic uncertainties. These methods will be employed to develop risk-bounded planning algorithms and a dynamic, probabilistic geofence to support autonomous air traffic integration in the NAS. The project will support graduate students and enhance the graduate program at San Diego State University, a Hispanic Serving Higher Education Institution. The PI will also use a simulation platform to engage K-12 and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, in the areas of aerospace engineering, information science, and artificial intelligence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Engineering Research Initiation (ERI) project focused on advancing safety and coordination strategies for autonomous aircraft—such as drones and air taxis—as they become increasingly integrated into the National Airspace System (NAS). With the growing presence of autonomous systems in commercial delivery, urban air mobility, and space launch corridors, ensuring safe and efficient operations in crowded and uncertain airspace is a major challenge. This project addressed that challenge through three tightly connected research thrusts that advanced the theory, modeling, and algorithms needed to support risk-aware, real-time planning in complex environments.

 

The first research thrust developed a method for learning how uncertainty affects the motion of autonomous systems by using real-world data instead of relying on simplified assumptions like Gaussian noise. Using a kernel density estimator (KDE) accelerated by fast Fourier transforms (FFT), we created a way to compute probabilistic reachable sets—regions where a vehicle is likely to remain with high confidence. This data-driven framework can model complex, irregular uncertainty and was designed to work efficiently enough to support real-time applications such as air traffic monitoring and collision avoidance.

 

The second thrust focused on using the uncertainty models developed in Thrust I to guide safe planning. Specifically, we created algorithms that use chance constraints to keep risk below a desired threshold. To make this work in real time, we developed optimization-based methods that approximate the uncertain regions as convex sets (polytopes or zonotopes), which are easier to use in planning algorithms. We proposed both exact formulations using mixed-integer optimization and fast heuristic methods to generate these convex shapes. These tools allow autonomous systems to make fast, reliable decisions that account for uncertainty in their environment—crucial for safe operations in dynamic, shared airspace.

 

In the third thrust, we tackled the challenge of coordinating many autonomous agents—such as drones—in shared airspace. We developed a multi-scale planning framework based on an adapted A* search algorithm that divides the airspace into grids of varying resolution. Finer detail is used locally (near the drone), while coarser representation is used farther away. This method significantly reduces the size of the search space, enabling real-time rolling planning as new information becomes available. To ensure the planner remains both efficient and reliable, we introduced a hybrid planning strategy that combines the multi-scale method with traditional A* for infeasible or edge-case scenarios. The result is a fast, scalable approach to drone traffic coordination that maintains a high level of safety and optimality.

 

Beyond technical innovation, the project contributed to several broader impacts: 1) Safety and Public Trust: The tools developed in this project help make autonomous air operations safer and more predictable, which is key to building public confidence in technologies like drone delivery and air taxis. 2) Education and Training: The project supported 2 PhD, 2 graduate and 2 undergraduate students in research at the intersection of aerospace and control systems. Students gained hands-on experience working with real flight data, developing algorithms, and testing solutions in simulation environments. These experiences prepare them for future careers in emerging technologies. 3) Broadening Participation in STEM: Conducted at San Diego State University, a Hispanic-Serving Institution, the project involved students from underrepresented backgrounds and engaged K–12 and undergraduate students through outreach and simulation-based demonstrations.

 

In summary, this ERI award supported fundamental research that will help enable the safe, efficient integration of autonomous vehicles into national airspace. The results not only address current technical challenges but also lay the groundwork for future innovations in autonomy, planning, and real-time safety assurance.
